children.subject: Taking 189 and 162 together sounds awful, and completely opposed with the aim of having "some time to myself outside of classes."

If you haven’t taken 126/127/140 or even Math 110, I would strongly advise against taking 189 unless you have a lot of prior ML experience. Shewchuks class is much more geometrical in nature but still requires a strong mathematical maturity. If you wanna get the most out of it take the pre-reqs if you don’t, it’ll be a struggle and you won’t like the material as much. Also taking it alongside 162 is for sure not recommended, 189 homework’s take a long time and afaik 162 is also high workload.

As an average student, if you're aiming to do well in 189, take one or more of the recommended classes for 189 (i.e. 126/140, 127). As an average student myself, I found that taking 126 made 189 considerably easier to get through since I had the probability intuition. The same could be said for taking 127 for lin alg intuition. In any case, don't take 189 now and definitely don't take it with 162 if your aim is to do reasonably well AND have time for yourself.

Thanks for all your responses, but I won't really have time to take 126/127/Stat 140 given the other courses I want to take before graduating that I believe are going to be more useful for my purposes. I was told that Shewchuk's 189 was the simplest to understand without having had past relevant experience, and I merely wanted a cursory glance of what ML at Berkeley looked like. Maybe I won't take 189 at all then.
Plus you can take the class P/NP anyway, if what you want is "a cursory glance of what ML at Berkeley looked like".

according to Shewchuck, the minimal prereqs are math 54/ee16 series, cs70, and math 53 (and I heard you only need a couple weeks of 53). More than a few people will be going in with just this experience, rest assured
Thanks for you feedback! Out of curiosity, which was your third upper div?
I wouldn't be able to take 189 P/NP next semester as I haven't finished all the upper div requirements yet since I have only taken 3 CS upper divs so far.

I agree that 189 and 162 combined sounds awful, but don’t feel discouraged by not having the recommended classes before taking 189! In my own experience prereqs are more for building familiarity/foundation with a concept rather than directly impactful on how you will do in the course. For example how much of math 1a/1b did you really need for math 54/EE16 series and how much CS70 did you really use in CS170? For sure it would be useful to have taken those classes prior, but like you mentioned, it’s probably not the best use of your time/semester if your end goal is not to get an A (if it is, different story). You seem to be driven by curiosity, which is valiant and only you know how well your foundation is and how well you can pick up difficult abstract material. Those prereqs may be the difference between an A/B+, not an A and F. your call; I believe in you either way! :)
Thanks for your feedback! Out of curiosity, what was your third upper div?

As an alternate and perhaps unconventional perspective, I think people have blown way out of proportions the mathematical maturity required for 189. 

For my personal background, I went in with none of ee126/ee127/math110/math54, no stat classes, no linalg/stats in high school, and very worried that 189 was going to destroy me given some of the things I have read on this Piazza. Upon hindsight, I took Shewchuk's 189 with only ee16ab/cs70/math53 and those classes were more than enough preparation, especially with the recent changes to 16ab. My courseload that semester was CS189 + CS162 + another CS upper div, which is essentially what OP is trying to do. It was a reasonably challenging semester, but I received A in all three classes with CS189 being the easiest of the three. Again, this is purely my personal experience/background and of course YMMV based on your own educational background/strengths/weaknesses. I would primarily like to point out to OP that what you are trying to take is certainly doable, so please don't be discouraged from giving it a shot. 

Furthermore, Shewchuk is an absolutely amazing and caring professor, and his lectures were short, approachable, covered a wide range of topics without being spread too thin, had a good mix of theory vs. applications (as opposed to some professors that try to drill in too much on the theory), and lastly consistent throughout the past few Shewchuk offerings, so you should have a very clear idea of what you are getting into.

I would hate for OP to be scared off this class by these "mathematical maturity" concerns, which while completely valid, can be overly intimidating. I recommend at least enrolling in or sitting in on the class for the first few weeks and see how things go; I wouldn't write off 189 (or any other class for that matter) based on Piazza comments weeks before the semester even begins :)

history.content: My guess as someone who took 189 with shewchuk having stat 140 and math 110 is that the class would be 10-30 hours a work a week the first month, as you get used to the rigorous math and struggle through the really mathy hw2 and learn/review the required probability/linear algebra for the class, then probably around 5-15 hours a week after that. You can make the first month easier by self studying the first few weeks and attempting hw2 before the semester starts. All materials are online.

How much work, in hours/week or some other possibly quantifiable metric, is Shewchuk's version of 189 for an otherwise average student who hasn't taken 126/127/Stat 140? I'm contemplating taking it next semester alongside 162 at the very least, and I also would like to have some time to myself outside of classes.
